key_behaviors: Uses ChatGPT and Claude daily for personal tasks
Employs AI as a thinking partner to get perspective on many topics
Feeds drafts of emails, texts, work documents, and even book chapters to AI for editing
Iteratively edits AI output, often multiple rounds before finalizing
Uses AI to summarize large amounts of publicly‑available data instead of consulting many people
Attempts to use AI for emotional support when a human is unavailable
Wishes AI could handle physical errands and household chores
pain_points: AI edits are often imperfect, requiring the user to make manual changes (“I don’t like to tell the AI what to change because it doesn’t always get it right”)
Conversational AI feels unsatisfying for emotional support – it “overdoes it” and talks too fast, lacking human nuance
Low overall trust in AI suggestions (rated 2 – Low trust)
Privacy and security concerns about giving AI access to logins, passwords, or credit‑card information
Voice‑only interview format feels unnatural and disjointed; AI cuts off or doesn’t pause long enough
trust_factors: Strong need for privacy and data security (“it should be like a Google robot with liability measures built in… that it won’t share my data with others”)
Desire for clear liability guarantees from the provider
Low trust in AI output despite frequent use
desires: An AI assistant that can perform physical tasks – run errands, clean the house, do laundry – to free up time for family
Seamless integration with existing tools (calendar, email, inbox) to automate manual chores
Better conversational flow: slower speech, appropriate pauses, more natural turn‑taking
A voice module that can read questions aloud naturally and avoid cutting the user off
Improved emotional‑support capability that feels less “clunky”

verbatim_quotes.quote: I use AI for a lot of things that I normally would have gone to a human for, but now I just do it a lot more.
verbatim_quotes.topic: AI as substitute for human input

verbatim_quotes.quote: When the thinking requires processing a lot of data that humans can't possibly access, the value lies in its ability to give me perspective based on a vast amount of publicly available data.
I might draft an email, and I will feed the AI my draft. Then I will ask it to edit it, and it will do that. After that, I might edit the AI's output and put it back in, asking it to edit it again.
I don't like to tell the AI what to change because it doesn't always get it right.
It's unsatisfying because it's not a real human. Also, I think as far as models go, they're just not there yet with this kind of information and this kind of interaction.
When I try, it's just unsatisfying… it would talk too fast. I would pause to think, and it would move ahead.
On average, how much do you trust the results or suggestions you get from AI tools? – 2 - Low trust
If I had a perfect AI assistant, it would run errands for me, clean the house, and do all sorts of tasks. So, it would need to move beyond the computer and chatbot space and venture into robotics.
Because those are tasks I don't value as much. I want my attention to be focused on connecting with other humans… Anything that would free up time for the three of us to connect… is important.
It should be like a Google robot with liability measures built in, and Google should guarantee that it won't share my data with others and that my security is protected.
This is weird because you're not talking and I'm talking. So I think I prefer the live experience better than this and that.
I don't know. I'm just not used to talking to myself, I guess, and I'm talking into something… it feels really strange.
The Wiser interface is pretty close; it only cut me off a couple of times… Now it's just about getting your voice module to come in and actually say the questions out loud.
verbatim_quotes.topic: Improvement suggestion for AI voice interaction

unique_insights: The participant heavily relies on AI for routine cognitive tasks (writing, data summarization) and treats it as a scalable substitute for consulting multiple human experts, yet still rates trust very low and refuses to grant it deep access to personal accounts. Their vision of an ideal assistant extends beyond software to embodied robotics that handle household chores, explicitly to protect time for family connection—a motivation that links task automation directly to emotional wellbeing rather than productivity alone.
